content:
The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" is also known as the Overseas Private Investment Corporation Act. It includes amendments to income levels and investment insurance ceilings. The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" (Overseas Private Investment Corporation Act) includes amendments to investment insurance and financing ceilings, as well as issuing authority and policy guidance updates. The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 by updating issuing authority and policy guidance. Section 233(b) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to remove certain sentences and specify the inclusion of key officials like the President of the Corporation, the Administrator of the Agency for International Development, and the United States Trade Representative. The amendment to Section 233(b) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 includes the addition of a Chairman and Vice Chairman of the Board, designated by the President, and allows the United States Trade Representative to appoint a Deputy to serve on the Board. The amendment adds a Chairman and Vice Chairman of the Board, designated by the President, and allows the U.S. Trade Representative to appoint a Deputy to serve on the Board. TITLE II--TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT AGENCY

SEC. 201. TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT AGENCY AUTHORIZATION.

Section 661(f)(1)(A) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to authorize $40,000,000 for fiscal 1997 and necessary sums for fiscal year 1998.

TITLE III--EXPORT PROMOTION PROGRAMS WITHIN THE INTERNATIONAL TRADE ADMINISTRATION

SEC. 301. EXPORT PROMOTION AUTHORIZATION. TITLE III--EXPORT PROMOTION PROGRAMS WITHIN THE INTERNATIONAL TRADE ADMINISTRATION

SEC. 301. EXPORT PROMOTION AUTHORIZATION.

Section 202 of the Export Administration Amendments Act of 1985 is amended to authorize $240,000,000 for fiscal year 1997 and necessary sums for fiscal year 1998. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to identify means for providing more coordinated export promotion services to small- and medium-sized businesses and establish priorities for promoting US exports and free market reforms in the Middle East to stimulate job growth. SEC. 402. IMPLEMENTATION OF PRIMARY OBJECTIVES. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee will identify and address overlap and duplication in Federal export promotion activities, promote better coordination between State, Federal, and private sector export promotion activities, and share market research data by September 30, 1997. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee aims to improve coordination between Federal, State, and private sector export promotion activities by promoting co-location, cost-sharing, and sharing market research data. These efforts will be included in the annual report by September 30, 1997. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee will report on activities to promote US trade and investment for private sector development in Ukraine in the 1997 annual report.
